column1: After the model has been conceptualized , coded , verified , and validated , it is ready to leave information through experimentation .

column1: Experimentation is the process of initializing key arguments in the model and setting up production runs to make inferences about the behavior of the system under study .
column2: Experimentation is the process of initializing key parameters in the model and setting up production runs to make inferences about the behavior of the system under study.

column1: The experimentation process consists of three steps : The first step in the experimentation process is experimental purpose .
column2: The experimentation process consists of three steps: The first step in the experimentation process is experimental design.

column1: The term experimental design implies that an experiment is being planned or set up .
column2: The term experimental design implies that an experiment is being designed or set up.

column1: This is done by identifying key arguments and initializing these parameters to values of interest .
column2: This is done by identifying key parameters and initializing these parameters to values of interest.

column1: They may be continuous or discrete .

column1: Random variables are selected by chance and are not influenced in any way by past values .
column2: Random variables are selected by chance and are not influenced in any way by past values.

column1: Random numbers are widely used in experiments that are dependent upon chance .
column2: Random numbers are widely used in experiments that are dependent upon chance.

column2: Random numbers can be generated in many different ways.

column2: The flip of a coin, drawing numbers from a hat, roulette wheels, and playing cards are examples of physical generation methods.

column2: The most common method of obtaining random numbers for use in the computer simulation field is through algebra.

column1: Terminating simulations are models that represent a system that begins in a particular state and then terminates or ends after a fixed period of time or when a predetermined condition is reached .
column2: Terminating simulations are models that represent a system that starts in a particular state and then terminates or ends after a fixed period of time or when a predetermined condition is reached.

column1: Terminating simulations are used to model particular manufacturing operations where the characteristics of the organization startup are important to include or in situations where a specific period of time is being analyzed , like weekend ticket sales for a newly released movie .
column2: Terminating simulations are used to model particular manufacturing operations where the characteristics of the system startup are important to include or in situations where a specific period of time is being analyzed, like weekend ticket sales for a newly released movie.

column1: Terminating simulations study a system over a predefined time period like a switch , a day , or a week .
column2: Terminating simulations study a system over a predefined time period like a shift, a day, or a week.

column1: An analyst using a terminating pretense makes no attempt to bring the model to a steady state or stable operating condition .

column1: ﻿Biological signal analysis1 embraces several interdisciplinary topics that deal with analysing signals generated by various physiological processes in the human body .
column2: ﻿Biological signal analysis1 encompasses several interdisciplinary topics that deal with analysing signals generated by various physiological processes in the human body.

column1: These signals could be electrical , chemical or acoustic in origin and an analysis of these signals are much useful in explaining and/or identifying pathological conditions of the human body .
column2: These signals could be electrical, chemical or acoustic in origin and an analysis of these signals are often useful in explaining and/or identifying pathological conditions of the human body.

column1: However , these signals in their rawest form do not provide much information and therefore , the motivation behind biological signal analysis is to extract ( i.e .
column2: However, these signals in their rawest form do not provide much information and therefore, the motivation behind biological signal analysis is to extract (i.e.

column1: This analysis has become even more important with modern healthcare striving to provide cost effective point-of care diagnosis and personalised treatment .
column2: This analysis has become even more important with modern healthcare striving to provide cost effective point-of care diagnosis and personalised treatment.

column1: Furthermore , fast computing power in recent years has made much of the more complex analysis methodologies potential .
column2: Furthermore, fast computing power in recent years has made much of the more complex analysis methodologies possible.

column1: The purpose of this chapter is to provide an overview of biological signal origins and describe normally encountered biological signals .
column2: The purpose of this chapter is to provide an overview of biological signal origins and describe commonly encountered biological signals.

column1: Before we delve into the analysis of biological signals , it would be utilitarian to understand that they are often represented as discrete in time .
column2: Before we delve into the analysis of biological signals, it would be useful to understand that they are often represented as discrete in time.

column1: For example , name 1.1 shows an example of a sinus rhythm electrocardiogram ( ECG ) , which represents the electrical activity obtained from normal heart .
column2: For example, Figure 1.1 shows an example of a sinus rhythm electrocardiogram (ECG), which represents the electrical activity obtained from normal heart.

column1: A single measurement of the signal x is a scalar and represents the electrical signals generated by the mechanisms in the heart ( the details of this process follow later ) at a particular instant of time t ( denoted with index n ) rather than at all points of time ( the involved sampling procedure to obtain discrete time measurements from continuous signals will be discussed in the following chapter ) .
column2: A single measurement of the signal x is a scalar and represents the electrical signals generated by the mechanisms in the heart (the details of this process follow later) at a particular instant of time t (denoted with index n) rather than at all points of time (the involved sampling process to obtain discrete time measurements from continuous signals will be discussed in the following chapter).

column1: There are two types of noise inherent in this signal : baseline and powerline interference .
column2: There are two types of noise inherent in this signal: baseline and powerline interference.

column2: This figure also shows a zoomed version of the ECG representing one beat of heart.

column1: Similarly , the segment from the Q wave to the S wave ( more commonly known as QRS segment ) , is utilitarian in indicating certain pathological2 variations in the heart’s electrical system .
column2: Similarly, the segment from the Q wave to the S wave (more commonly known as QRS segment), is useful in indicating certain pathological2 variations in the heart’s electrical system.

column1: For example , name 1.3 shows an ECG waveform from a subject with an ectopic beat of Premature Ventricular Contraction ( PVC ) type .
column2: For example, Figure 1.3 shows an ECG waveform from a subject with an ectopic beat of Premature Ventricular Contraction (PVC) type.

column1: Ectopic beats are premature beats with a complex waveform that can occur occasionally in most people .
column2: Ectopic beats are premature beats with a complex waveform that can occur occasionally in most people.

column1: However , the presence of frequent ectopic beats ( more than six per minute ) could indicate a serious fatal trouble if left uncorrected .
column2: However, the presence of frequent ectopic beats (more than six per minute) could indicate a serious fatal problem if left uncorrected.

column1: While it is visually obvious that the QRS segment for the PVC beat is different from name 1.1 , it is impractical to sit and manually detect the occurrences from an ECG chart ( or on-screen monitor ) of a patient over many hours/days .
column2: While it is visually obvious that the QRS segment for the PVC beat is different from Figure 1.1, it is impractical to sit and manually detect the occurrences from an ECG chart (or on-screen monitor) of a patient over many hours/days.

column1: Rather , a computer that is trained to automatically analyse and detect the occurrence of such beats using signal processing algorithms is used .
column2: Rather, a computer that is trained to automatically analyse and detect the occurrence of such beats using signal processing algorithms is employed.

column2: This is a typical biological signal analysis application.

column2: Figure 1.4 shows the typical signal analysis methodologies involved that would be necessary for such a computer based detection of ectopic beats; the details of which will be discussed generally in the forthcoming chapters and specifically in the final chapter.

column1: Commonly found biological signals that describe the electrical activity of the brain , heart , muscles etc will be introduced in this section .
column2: Commonly encountered biological signals that describe the electrical activity of the brain, heart, muscles etc will be introduced in this section.

column1: Some of these signals like ECG and electroencephalogram ( EEG ) are spontaneous activity of the human body while others such as evoked potentials are signals in response to external stimulus , for example the presentation of visual stimuli which results in visual evoked potential ( VEP ) signals .
column2: Some of these signals like ECG and electroencephalogram (EEG) are spontaneous activity of the human body while others such as evoked potentials are signals in response to external stimulus, for example the presentation of visual stimuli which results in visual evoked potential (VEP) signals.

column1: While some analysis procedures are common ( like using filters to extract components in specific frequency range ) , the different properties of these biological signals make call for the application of widely varying analysis procedures .
column2: While some analysis procedures are common (like using filters to extract components in specific frequency range), the different properties of these biological signals do call for the application of widely varying analysis procedures.

column1: Hence , it is useful to know the fundamental details of how these signals are generated before studying analysis procedures for extraction of the needed information .
column2: Hence, it is useful to know the fundamental details of how these signals are generated before studying analysis procedures for extraction of the required information.

column1: The ECG is a representation of the electrical activity of the heart and the cardiac rhythm is controlled by the pacemaker cells known as sinoatrial ( SA ) node .
column2: The ECG is a representation of the electrical activity of the heart and the cardiac rhythm is controlled by the pacemaker cells known as sinoatrial (SA) node.

column1: The PQRST waveform ( as shown in Figure 1.5 ) represents one complete ECG cycle : P wave occurs when SA node fires and the impulse spreads across atria and triggers atrial contraction ; PQ interval ( isometric segment ) is the generation delay when the impulse travels from atria to ventricles ( allowing blood flow to complete in similar direction ) ; QRS complex occurs when the impulse spreads to ventricles and triggers ventricular contraction ; ST segment is the period when the ventricles are depolarised and ventricular repolarisation ( relaxation ) begins and T wave represents the return to resting state by the ventricles [ 2 ] .
column2: The PQRST waveform (as shown in Figure 1.5) represents one complete ECG cycle: P wave occurs when SA node fires and the impulse spreads across atria and triggers atrial contraction; PQ interval (isometric segment) is the propagation delay when the impulse travels from atria to ventricles (allowing blood flow to complete in similar direction); QRS complex occurs when the impulse spreads to ventricles and triggers ventricular contraction; ST segment is the period when the ventricles are depolarised and ventricular repolarisation (relaxation) begins and T wave represents the return to resting state by the ventricles [2].

column1: These electrical impulses are normally recorded through electrodes placed on especial areas of the body either using 12-channel ECG in a hospital or 3-channel ECG in the field .
column2: These electrical impulses are normally recorded through electrodes placed on particular areas of the body either using 12-channel ECG in a hospital or 3-channel ECG in the field.

column1: name 1.6 shows the hypothetical Einthoven’s triangle that is commonly used for the electrode setup .
column2: Figure 1.6 shows the hypothetical Einthoven’s triangle that is commonly used for the electrode setup.

column1: The setup requires four limb electrodes placed on the right and left arms and legs ; the fourth limb electrode that is not shown in the diagram is placed on the correct leg and serves as reference channel .
column2: The setup requires four limb electrodes placed on the right and left arms and legs; the fourth limb electrode that is not shown in the diagram is placed on the right leg and serves as reference channel.

column1: The top of the Einthoven’s triangulum forms Lead I , while the left forms Lead II and right forms Lead III .
column2: The top of the Einthoven’s triangle forms Lead I, while the left forms Lead II and right forms Lead III.

column1: Each lead represents a unlike aspect of the heart’s electrical system .
column2: Each lead represents a different aspect of the heart’s electrical system.

column1: The voltage differences between the limb electrodes : left arm ( LA ) , right arm ( RA ) , and left leg ( LL ) are used to obtain Leads I , II and III [ 3 , 4 ] : It should be obvious that the three leads have the relationship : These three leads are normally sufficient to detect life threatening abnormal ECG rhythms ( arrhythmias ) and will frequently be used in this book .
column2: The voltage differences between the limb electrodes: left arm (LA), right arm (RA), and left leg (LL) are used to obtain Leads I, II and III [3, 4]: It should be obvious that the three leads have the relationship: These three leads are normally sufficient to detect life threatening abnormal ECG rhythms (arrhythmias) and will often be used in this book.

column1: ﻿How better to archive and mine the complex data derived from HCS experiments that provides a series of challenges associated with both the methods used to elicit the RNAi response and the functional data gathered ?
column2: ﻿How best to archive and mine the complex data derived from HCS experiments that provides a series of challenges associated with both the methods used to elicit the RNAi response and the functional data gathered?

column1: To enable effective data retrieval for HCS experiments , data and pictures and associated information must be stored with high integrity and in a readable form .
column2: To enable effective data retrieval for HCS experiments, data and images and associated information must be stored with high integrity and in a readable form.

column1: HCS data should be stored in a form that takes advantage of the characteristics of this type of data to enable full access , analysis and exploitation of the data .
column2: HCS data should be stored in a form that takes advantage of the characteristics of this type of data to enable full access, analysis and exploitation of the data.

column1: A key factor is the database model which represents data in logical form .
column2: A key factor is the database model which represents data in logical form.

column1: The data model ( or database structure or database schema ) should be flexible to handle the various HCS data types ( i.e. , compound information , results : image data and derived metadata ) , experiment simulation and a wide range of changes in the data ( e.g. , different numbers of wells , cells , features , images , different picture sizes and formats , different number of time-points , and so on ) .
column2: The data model (or database structure or database schema) should be flexible to handle the various HCS data types (i.e., compound information, results: image data and derived metadata), experiment simulation and a wide range of changes in the data (e.g., different numbers of wells, cells, features, images, different image sizes and formats, different number of time-points, and so on).

column1: The structure of the data model provides a way of describing data and the relationships within the data , enabling data to be formed , cataloged , and searched effectively .
column2: The structure of the data model provides a way of describing data and the relationships within the data, enabling data to be organized, cataloged, and searched effectively.

column1: Databases where a database model is implemented enable joining of related data to leave meaningful visualization , analysis , and data mining .
column2: Databases where a database model is implemented enable joining of related data to allow meaningful visualization, analysis, and data mining.

column1: The data model is also important for integration with other organizations .
column2: The data model is also important for integration with other systems.

column1: HCS data are containing three types of data : 1 .
column2: HCS data are containing three types of data: 1.

column1: Database of compounds ( RNAi or minor molecules ) .
column2: Database of compounds (RNAi or small molecules).

column1: Numbers of pictures that require significant amounts of storage .
column2: Numbers of images that require significant amounts of storage.

column1: Numbers of files including image processing arguments .
column2: Numbers of files including image processing parameters.

column1: Meta-data .
column2: Meta-data.

column1: therefore , a large amount of data is collected for just one well of a single plate .
column2: Thus, a large amount of data is collected for just one well of a single plate.

column1: In addition , early associated information about the assay or experiment , such as protocol information , is also typically recorded .
column2: In addition, other associated information about the assay or experiment, such as protocol information, is also typically recorded.

column1: Having four types of data is easy to define three general categories of HCS data : - Image data : These are the pictures acquired at each channel for each field within a well and produced thumbnails for visualization purposes - Numeric Results data : these are the measurements that result from performing an analysis on an image with image analysis algorithms .
column2: Having four types of data is easy to define three general categories of HCS data: - Image data: These are the images acquired at each channel for each field within a well and produced thumbnails for visualization purposes - Numeric Results data: these are the measurements that result from performing an analysis on an image with image analysis algorithms.

column1: - Metadata : These are the associated data that leave context for the other two categories of data ( i.e. , metadata are data that describes other data ) .
column2: - Metadata: These are the associated data that provide context for the other two categories of data (i.e., metadata are data that describes other data).

column1: Examples are : well – compound annotation , assay type , plate information , protocols , operators , calculated data such as dose–response values , as well as annotations imported from other organizations .
column2: Examples are: well – compound annotation, assay type, plate information, protocols, operators, calculated data such as dose–response values, as well as annotations imported from other systems.

column1: Let’s try to understand how data are produced .
column2: Let’s try to understand how data are produced.

column1: HCS microscopes typically scan multiwell plates .
column2: HCS microscopes typically scan multiwell plates.

column1: These plates typically have 96 , 384 , or 1536 wells .
column2: These plates typically have 96, 384, or 1536 wells.

column1: Each well is a container in the plate that contains an individual sample of cells .
column2: Each well is a container in the plate that contains an individual sample of cells.

column1: Each well is divided into multiple fields .
column2: Each well is divided into multiple fields.

column1: Each field is a region of a well that represents an area to picture .
column2: Each field is a region of a well that represents an area to image.

column1: Each field consists of multiple pictures , one for each individual wavelength of light ( referred to as a “channel” , “staining” ) , corresponding to the fluorescent markers/probes used for the biology/dye of interest ( e.g. , DAPI ) .
column2: Each field consists of multiple images, one for each individual wavelength of light (referred to as a “channel”, “staining”), corresponding to the fluorescent markers/probes used for the biology/dye of interest (e.g., DAPI).

column1: There are typically between two and four channels per field ( e.g. , each channel shows unlike elements of the cells : 1 channel nuclei , 2 channel : cell membranes , 3 channel : endosomes , and so on ) .
column2: There are typically between two and four channels per field (e.g., each channel shows different elements of the cells: 1 channel nuclei, 2 channel: cell membranes, 3 channel: endosomes, and so on).

column1: The pictures produced are immediately analyzed using automated image processing .
column2: The images produced are immediately analyzed using automated image processing.

column1: Experiment results are produced .
column2: Experiment results are produced.

column1: Each well is seeded with a certain number of cells which has to be detected by picture processing algorithms .
column2: Each well is seeded with a certain number of cells which has to be detected by image processing algorithms.

column1: The cell act counted is a basic parameter used for the quality control of automation , microscopy or assay performance .
column2: The cell number counted is a basic parameter used for the quality control of automation, microscopy or assay performance.

column1: The number of cells per well varies depending on the experiment , but typically ranges between 5 and 10000 cells .
column2: The number of cells per well varies depending on the experiment, but typically ranges between 5 and 10000 cells.

column1: Very often images from well fields are merged into one picture using montage function .
column2: Very often images from well fields are merged into one image using montage function.

column1: For each cell , multiple object features ( or measurements ) are calculated by automated picture processing .
column2: For each cell, multiple object features (or measurements) are calculated by automated image processing.

column1: The cell has include measurements such as size , shape , intensity , and so on .
column2: The cell features include measurements such as size, shape, intensity, and so on.

column1: The number of cell features calculated varies depending on the assay , but typically ranges between 5 and 500.Those features have to be carefully investigated , filtered and only arguments should be considered for hit definition .
column2: The number of cell features calculated varies depending on the assay, but typically ranges between 5 and 500.Those features have to be carefully investigated, filtered and only parameters should be considered for hit definition.

column1: In addition , cell features are much aggregated to the well level to provide well level statistics ( one well one row labeled with plate annotation and position as unique identify ) .
column2: In addition, cell features are often aggregated to the well level to provide well level statistics (one well one row labeled with plate annotation and position as unique identify).

column1: The total storage size for experiments is primarily based on the acquired image data , image thumbnails , library data and the numeric results data .
column2: The total storage size for experiments is primarily based on the acquired image data, image thumbnails, library information and the numeric results data.

column1: The amount of data , learning and processing time varies depending on a number of factors including the type of assay , the number of plates , the type of the screen ( primary , secondary ) , available computational hardware , the throughput of the instrument or analysis application and the number of instruments which can work parallel .
column2: The amount of data, acquisition and processing time varies depending on a number of factors including the type of assay, the number of plates, the type of the screen (primary, secondary), available computational hardware, the throughput of the instrument or analysis application and the number of instruments which can work parallel.

column1: Table 2 demonstrates case experiments and summarizes necessary time , number of records and require for storage space .
column2: Table 2 demonstrates example experiments and summarizes necessary time, number of records and require for storage space.

column1: The size of the library information and numeric results data are counted in megabytes .
column2: The size of the library information and numeric results data are counted in megabytes.

column1: Numeric results are estimated by the number of feature records ( lines in tables ) .
column2: Numeric results are estimated by the number of feature records (lines in tables).

column1: Image storage depends on the number of pictures acquired .
column2: Image storage depends on the number of images acquired.

column1: The number of pictures depends on plate number , plate type ( 96 , 384 , 1536 ) , number of fields , number of channels , confocality levels and eventually time points in case of kincetic studies .
column2: The number of images depends on plate number, plate type (96, 384, 1536 ), number of fields, number of channels, confocality levels and eventually time points in case of kincetic studies.

column1: The typical picture size acquired ranges between 500KB and 2 MB ( single slice , single tiff file without montage ) .
column2: The typical image size acquired ranges between 500KB and 2 MB (single slice, single tiff file without montage).

column1: Thumbnails of those pictures often are generated using jpeg compression , their size range between 150- 300 kb .
column2: Thumbnails of those images often are generated using jpeg compression, their size range between 150- 300 kb.

column1: For numeric results data are categorized in three types of outputs : cell based , image based and well established .
column2: For numeric results data are categorized in three types of outputs: cell based, image based and well based.

column1: The number of image established record should be equal to the number of acquired images which is also equal to the number of thumbnails produced .
column2: The number of image based record should be equal to the number of acquired images which is also equal to the number of thumbnails produced.

column1: The record number of well established results data should be equal to the number of all wells in screening experiment .
column2: The record number of well based results data should be equal to the number of all wells in screening experiment.

column1: In high content informatics , the numeric data are supported by the pictures and the validation of numeric data is based on the visual inspection of images .
column2: In high content informatics, the numeric data are supported by the images and the validation of numeric data is based on the visual inspection of images.

column1: Any high content informatics solution therefore needs to be able to efficiently handle the relationships between the various levels of numeric results data , library information and the associated pictures .
column2: Any high content informatics solution therefore needs to be able to efficiently handle the relationships between the various levels of numeric results data, library information and the associated images.

column1: In the next subsection we will describe a database model ( schema ) and a database solution for handling library data , pictures and numeric results data .
column2: In the next subsection we will describe a database model (schema) and a database solution for handling library data, images and numeric results data.

column1: ( Burnley , 1983:145 ) Around 1387 ( Skeat , 1965:5 ) , when Chaucer wrote his Tales , the language - Middle English - had been and was under the influence of foreign languages ( Barber , 1993:140 ) and in this essay I mean to study the different types of loan-words in the 'Prologue ' to the Canterbury Tales .

column2: (Barber, 1993:151) However, the French of the Normans who invaded England in 1066 (The Battle of Hastings) was not the 'standard language' of France, but a dialect called Anglo-Norman.

column1: ( Barber , 1993:107 ) The loan-words at that time had to do with the fresh religion - priest , mass and vicar , ( Wilton ) but since the Normans became more influential in society as a whole , their language came to spread out French and/or Anglo-Norman words in many vocabulary areas .
column2: ( Barber, 1993:107) The loan-words at that time had to do with the new religion - priest, mass and vicar, (Wilton) but since the Normans became more influential in society as a whole, their language came to spread out French and/or Anglo-Norman words in many vocabulary areas.

column1: ( Wilton ) 3.2 Morphology The largest change in morphology , during the Middle English period , is the bang-up loss of the Old English inflections .
column2: (Wilton)  3.2 Morphology  The largest change in morphology, during the Middle English period, is the great loss of the Old English inflections.

column1: ( Barber , 1993:160 ) 3.3 Syntax The vocabulary change , in turn , meant that the order of the words in a sentence became more significant .
column2: (Barber, 1993:160)   3.3 Syntax  The vocabulary change, in turn, meant that the order of the words in a sentence became more important.

column1: Since it in Old English was possible to tell from the endings of the words which function each word had in the sentence , word-order was not very significant .
column2: Since it in Old English was possible to tell from the endings of the words which function each word had in the sentence, word-order was not very important.

column1: Old English had about the like freedom as Latin when it came to placing the words in a phrase , but when these endings disappeared users of the language had to begin to rely on word-order .
column2: Old English had about the same freedom as Latin when it came to placing the words in a phrase, but when these endings disappeared users of the language had to begin to rely on word-order.

column1: ﻿ Would a Spelling Reform of the English Language constitute an Improvement ?
column2: ﻿ Would a Spelling Reform of the English Language be an Improvement?

column1: It is entirely in recent years that linguists have grasped what considerable differences there are between our two channels of language .
column2: It is only in recent years that linguists have grasped what considerable differences there are between our two channels of language.

column1: To a bombastic extent their improved knowledge has been promoted by the tape-recorder ( Milroy & Milroy , 1985 ) .
column2: To a large extent their improved knowledge has been promoted by the tape-recorder (Milroy & Milroy, 1985).

column1: To give some cases of differences that may cause confusion we still , as is well known , preserve letters in our spelling that represent sounds which long ago ceased to be pronounced , such as -p in the word receipt .
column2: To give some examples of differences that may cause confusion we still, as is well known, preserve letters in our spelling that represent sounds which long ago ceased to be pronounced, such as -p in the word receipt.

column1: Distinctions are commonly made in spelling where there is no longer a distinction in pronounciation .
column2: Distinctions are commonly made in spelling where there is no longer a distinction in pronounciation.

column1: The pairs sea/see and meat/meet are entirely two out of many of the same kind .
column2: The pairs sea/see and meat/meet are only two out of many of the same kind.

column1: On the opposite side we have become distinctions that have emerged in speech without any trace of it to be seen in writing .
column2: On the opposite side we have got distinctions that have emerged in speech without any trace of it to be seen in writing.

column1: Think for example of the spelling -ng in singer and finger .
column2: Think for example of the spelling -ng in singer and finger.

column1: It is the exact like .
column2: It is the exact same.

column1: When it comes to diphthongs we can much see them represented by a single letter , such as -i in mice .
column2: When it comes to diphthongs we can often see them represented by a single letter, such as -i in mice.

column1: Conversely , modern phonemes that are definitely arrant vowels can sometimes be represented by so called digraphs .
column2: Conversely, modern phonemes that are definitely pure vowels can sometimes be represented by so called digraphs.

column1: An example of a digraph would be the -au of writer ( Barber , 1993 ) .
column2: An example of a digraph would be the -au of author (Barber, 1993).

column1: As we have seen then there is a bang-up number of inconsistencies to be found in the English spelling system and one result of those inconsistencies is the prevalence of so called spelling-pronounciations .
column2: As we have seen then there is a great number of inconsistencies to be found in the English spelling system and one result of those inconsistencies is the prevalence of so called spelling-pronounciations.

column1: These arise when a word is given a fresh pronounciation through the influence of its spelling ( ibid ) .
column2: These arise when a word is given a new pronounciation through the influence of its spelling (ibid).

column1: One example of this is the preferably common re-introduction of -t in often .
column2: One example of this is the rather common re-introduction of -t in often.

column1: According to Barber ( 1993:202 ) spelling-pronounciations are peculiarly likely to appear when `` universal education and the wide dissemination of books and newspapers introduce people to words in printed form which they have never heard pronounced in their home environment '' .
column2: According to Barber (1993:202) spelling-pronounciations are particularly likely to appear when "universal education and the wide dissemination of books and newspapers introduce people to words in printed form which they have never heard pronounced in their home environment".

column1: In other words it is quite likely that foreigners will pronounce words in the 'wrong ' direction , whereas natives on the other hand are more likely to have difficulties when in comes to spelling , since there are so many inconsistencies in it .
column2: In other words it is quite likely that foreigners will pronounce words in the 'wrong' way, whereas natives on the other hand are more likely to have difficulties when in comes to spelling, since there are so many inconsistencies in it.

column1: The latter group of people are continuously exposed to the 'correct ' means of pronouncing words .
column2: The latter group of people are continuously exposed to the 'correct' ways of pronouncing words.

column1: Due to all the likely difficulties there are then , it has sometimes been suggested that a spelling reform of the English language would be an improvement .
column2: Due to all the potential difficulties there are then, it has sometimes been suggested that a spelling reform of the English language would be an improvement.

column1: In this essay my intention is consequently to discuss whether such a reform is preferable or not and why .
column2: In this essay my intention is therefore to discuss whether such a reform is preferable or not and why.

column1: I will put forward arguments both in favour of and against a spelling reform , even though the latter ones are going to dominate .
column2: I will put forward arguments both in favour of and against a spelling reform, even though the latter ones are going to dominate.

column1: I find it important to reflect upon implications of actions taken in either management .
column2: I find it important to reflect upon implications of actions taken in either direction.

column1: What happens in the short term as well as in the long term position if we decide not to change the spelling system ?
column2: What happens in the short term as well as in the long term perspective if we decide not to change the spelling system?

column1: What happens if we do ?
column2: What happens if we do?

column1: Before I proceed to a discussion I will , in the following paragraph , give you the reader a brief historical background .
column2: Before I proceed to a discussion I will, in the following paragraph, give you the reader a brief historical background.

column1: Hopefully that will make matters more interesting and easy to follow .
column2: Hopefully that will make things more interesting and easy to follow.

column1: Today , in the twentieth century , spelling is almost absolutely invariant .
column2: Today, in the twentieth century, spelling is almost absolutely invariant.

column1: Earlier on though , in both Middle and Early Modern English , a limited number of alternatives were satisfactory .
column2: Earlier on though, in both Middle and Early Modern English, a limited number of alternatives were acceptable.

column1: Informal spelling was actually fairly common as late as in the eighteenth century and rather surprisingly different spellings could be seen even within the study of each writer ( Barber , 1993 ) .
column2: Informal spelling was actually fairly common as late as in the eighteenth century and rather surprisingly different spellings could be seen even within the work of each writer (Barber, 1993).

column1: Milroy and Milroy ( 1985 ) both stresses the fact that the idea of an absolutely fixed spelling system is recent .
column2: Milroy and Milroy (1985) both stresses the fact that the idea of an absolutely fixed spelling system is recent.

column1: They state that particular spellings of words nowadays are regarded as uniquely satisfactory and that other possible spellings are being rejected as 'errors ' .
column2: They state that particular spellings of words nowadays are regarded as uniquely acceptable and that other possible spellings are being rejected as 'errors'.

column1: It is significant , they mean , to bear in mind that the accepted forms are arbitrary and fixed by convention .
column2: It is important, they mean, to bear in mind that the accepted forms are arbitrary and fixed by convention.

column1: No spellings are in themselves more legitimate than others .
column2: No spellings are in themselves more logical than others.

column1: According to Barber ( 1993 ) a ruled language is one in which satisfactory usage is explicitly laid down .
column2: According to Barber (1993) a ruled language is one in which acceptable usage is explicitly laid down.

column1: He describes in detail how sealed linguists in the past used to believe that rules and regulations would prevent the language from changing .

column1: ﻿ THE INCREASING NUMBER OF YOUTHS USING DRUGS AT LOWER AGES Resent studies has shown that drug usage is increasing and that narcotics exist in closer contact with younger students .
column2: ﻿ THE INCREASING NUMBER OF YOUTHS USING DRUGS AT LOWER AGES  Resent studies has shown that drug usage is increasing and that narcotics exist in closer contact with younger students.

column1: According to the CAN survey , 1 out of 10 students attending the 9th grade of the senior level has on one or respective occasions used drugs .
column2: According to the CAN survey, 1 out of 10 students attending the 9th grade of the senior level has on one or several occasions used drugs.

column1: Compared with statistic surveys from 1995 this is an increase by 50 % .
column2: Compared with statistic surveys from 1995 this is an increase by 50%.

column1: The results are in line with early inquiries ; for example , a study made by the social welfare service which is a 5 year long investigation series on students ' , in the second grade , upper secondary school , drug habits .
column2: The results are in line with other inquiries; for example, a study made by the social welfare service which is a 5 year long investigation series on students', in the second grade, upper secondary school, drug habits.

column1: According to the latter , 1 out of 5 pupils has tried narcotics .
column2: According to the latter, 1 out of 5 pupils has tried narcotics.

column1: Of the ones that have used drugs , 40 % were under the age of 16 and 11 % under the age of 13 ( 1995 : 3 % ) the first time they tried narcotics .
column2: Of the ones that have used drugs, 40% were under the age of 16 and 11% under the age of 13 (1995: 3%) the first time they tried narcotics.

column1: Both studies show that the debut age for drug function has gone down and that the usage is increasing .
column2: Both studies show that the debut age for drug use has gone down and that the usage is increasing.

column1: They also demonstrate that the pupils ' attitudes towards drugs and drug policies have become more liberal than before .
column2: They also demonstrate that the pupils' attitudes towards drugs and drug policies have become more liberal than before.

column1: Why then , do more and more new students take drugs ?
column2: Why then, do more and more young students take drugs?

column1: One answer to this question could be the students more liberal and tolerant attitude toward drugs the youths ignore and disclaim the dangers with drugs ( according to the police authorities ) .
column2: One answer to this question could be the students more liberal and tolerant attitude toward drugs the youths ignore and disclaim the dangers with drugs (according to the police authorities).

column1: In an article about drug abuse , one could learn about a seventeen-year-old boy using ecstasy almost every weekend .
column2: In an article about drug abuse, one could read about a seventeen-year-old boy using ecstasy almost every weekend.

column1: He described the information received in school , concerning narcotics , to be very one-sided and that he felt he could n't relate to it .
column2: He described the information received in school, concerning narcotics, to be very one-sided and that he felt he couldn't relate to it.

column1: I think he is making an significant point .
column2: I think he is making an important point.

column1: The information you receive in school often describe worn-out drug addicts sleeping in street corners , and imply that that is where you will end up if you take drugs .
column2: The information you receive in school often describe worn-out drug addicts sleeping in street corners, and imply that that is where you will end up if you take drugs.

column1: Although it is not wholly unlikely that something like this could happen to you , if using drugs , it is very difficult for new pupils to identify themselves with this picture .
column2: Although it is not wholly unlikely that something like this could happen to you, if using drugs, it is very difficult for young pupils to identify themselves with this picture.

column1: There is a big difference between this and taking a few pills at private parties on weekends , many of these new users are often well behaved and very social , which makes the gap and differences between them and freaked-out addicts seem huge .
column2: There is a big difference between this and taking a few pills at private parties on weekends, many of these young users are often well behaved and very social, which makes the gap and differences between them and freaked-out addicts seem huge.

column1: Another cause to the increasing number of younger students using drugs could be due to high group pressure and a desire to fit in .
column2: Another cause to the increasing number of younger students using drugs could be due to high group pressure and a desire to fit in.

column1: Youths are very vulnerable and easily involved when they are in their early teens .
column2: Youths are very vulnerable and easily affected when they are in their early teens.

column1: Most of them are trying to figure out who they are , how to act and are often deadly afraid of being classified as outsiders .
column2: Most of them are trying to figure out who they are, how to act and are often deadly afraid of being classified as outsiders.

column1: It is commonly known that most people who start smoking do it because they want to meet in , to belong to a group or just want to be accepted , the same goes for drinking alcohol .
column2: It is commonly known that most people who start smoking do it because they want to fit in, to belong to a group or just want to be accepted, the same goes for drinking alcohol.

column1: Taking drugs is the third step some of us take in order to be accepted .
column2: Taking drugs is the third step some of us take in order to be accepted.

column1: Drugs have become the new rage and are used as a supplement to alcohol and smoking .
column2: Drugs have become the new rage and are used as a supplement to alcohol and smoking.

column1: You may think that narcotics are a considerable more dangerous mean of intoxication and that people can and do say no , but keep in mind that most youths get in contact with narcotics when they are very new and at such early ages , it is not easy to say no .
column2: You may think that narcotics are a considerable more dangerous mean of intoxication and that people can and do say no, but keep in mind that most youths get in contact with narcotics when they are very young and at such early ages, it is not easy to say no.

column1: The desire to fit in makes you do about anything .
column2: The desire to fit in makes you do almost anything.

column1: Also , when living such in close contact with drugs where they are easy to obtain , which school pupils do nowadays , they are running a high risk of trying it themselves .
column2: Also, when living such in close contact with drugs where they are easy to obtain, which school pupils do nowadays, they are running a high risk of trying it themselves.

column1: The more that start using drugs , the more will follow .
column2: The more that start using drugs, the more will follow.

column1: Some early factors contributing to this increase are , to begin with , the fact that it is n't very likely that you will be caught by the police .
column2: Some other factors contributing to this increase are, to begin with, the fact that it isn't very likely that you will be caught by the police.

column1: Most youths take drugs almost exclusively at private parties and usually know the person selling them their narcotics , from before .
column2: Most youths take drugs almost exclusively at private parties and usually know the person selling them their narcotics, from before.

column1: Another factor is that Sweden has not had that many problems with drugs in the past , it has not been one of the bigger social issues and I believe that is why this problem has been able to expand more freely .
column2: Another factor is that Sweden has not had that many problems with drugs in the past, it has not been one of the bigger social issues and I believe that is why this problem has been able to expand more freely.

column1: The number of ecstasy pills confiscated thus far this year goes up to 150 000 , compared with last years 75 000 pills .
column2: The number of ecstasy pills confiscated so far this year goes up to 150 000, compared with last years 75 000 pills.

column1: This trend will continue on getting bigger and bigger if we are unable to work out some sort of solution or way to stop it in the nearer future .
column2: This trend will keep on getting bigger and bigger if we are unable to work out some sort of solution or way to stop it in the nearer future.

column1: The expansion of narcotics in Sweden is being made very fast , which makes this is a problem that needs to be paid attention to and to be acknowledged by society .
column2: The expansion of narcotics in Sweden is being made very fast, which makes this is a problem that needs to be paid attention to and to be acknowledged by society.

column1: ﻿y foremost actual contact with the English language was in third grade in compulsory school .
column2: ﻿y first actual contact with the English language was in third grade in compulsory school.

column1: I remember I was actually looking forward to it .
column2: I remember I was really looking forward to it.

column1: I was going to determine how to speak and read in a foreign language .
column2: I was going to learn how to speak and read in a foreign language.

column1: It felt like it made me turn up a little bit !
column2: It felt like it made me grow up a little bit!

column1: I do n't remember how many English lessons we had a week at that time but I remember that a teacher came to our small school only for those occasions .
column2: I don't remember how many English lessons we had a week at that time but I remember that a teacher came to our little school only for those occasions.

column1: I suppose my ordinary teacher was n't certificated for it or just did n't want to teach English .
column2: I suppose my ordinary teacher wasn't certificated for it or simply didn't want to teach English.

column1: Well , I wished learning some English words and I liked the English lessons for the rest of compulsory school as well .
column2: Well, I liked learning some English words and I liked the English lessons for the rest of compulsory school as well.

column1: And it was pretty cool to be able to speak some when being abroad , in Greece for example .
column2: And it was pretty cool to be able to speak some when being abroad, in Greece for example.

column1: At senior high school though , I made of some reason lose my interest for English .
column2: At senior high school though, I did of some reason lose my interest for English.

column1: I found it like everyone in my class was doing much better than me .
column2: I felt it like everyone in my class was doing much better than me.

column1: Many of my friends had been to England or the United States taking language courses during some weeks in the summer .
column2: Many of my friends had been to England or the United States taking language courses during some weeks in the summer.

column1: nowadays when looking back at that time I do n't think I actually was much worse than the others , perhaps instead bad self-confidence was the reason why I was n't so active on the English lessons .
column2: Now when looking back at that time I don't think I actually was much worse than the others, perhaps instead bad self-confidence was the reason why I wasn't so active on the English lessons.

column1: Of course I did make the exercises in the books , read what we were supposed to read and answer the questions I got .
column2: Of course I did do the exercises in the books, read what we were supposed to read and answer the questions I got.

column1: But I did n't throw myself into discussions though , and speeches in front of the class were n't exactly 'my cup of tea ' .
column2: But I didn't throw myself into discussions though, and speeches in front of the class weren't exactly 'my cup of tea'.

column1: One year after senior high school , I got to know about a one semester English class in Portslade near Brighton in Great Britain .
column2: One year after senior high school, I got to know about a one semester English course in Portslade near Brighton in Great Britain.

column1: It is a course you apply for through Visings Folk High School in Sweden .
column2: It is a course you apply for through Visings Folk High School in Sweden.

column1: There are only Swedish students on the path but all teachers and staffs are Englishmen/women .
column2: There are only Swedish students on the course but all teachers and staffs are Englishmen/women.

column1: And your accommodation during the course is with an English class .
column2: And your accommodation during the course is with an English family.

column1: I went there hoping to improve my English and also to become a glimpse of British society and culture .
column2: I went there hoping to improve my English and also to get a glimpse of British society and culture.

column1: This was accordingly the inaugural time I was really forced to speak English .
column2: This was accordingly the first time I was really forced to speak English.

column1: I was surprised how comfortable it was to get into the language .
column2: I was surprised how easy it was to get into the language.

column1: I surely made lots of grammatically mistakes but that was n't so important at that moment .
column2: I surely did lots of grammatically mistakes but that wasn't so important at that moment.

column1: The independent thing was that I actually dared to speak and put my trust in that people understood me .
column2: The main thing was that I actually dared to speak and put my trust in that people understood me.

column1: I think the better way of learning a language , is to stay in a country where that language is spoken , for a while .
column2: I think the best way of learning a language, is to stay in a country where that language is spoken, for a while.

column1: Of course we studied grammar , wrote essays and so on the path , but I think I learn most just by listening , speaking and constantly being `` surrounded by English '' , written and spoken .
column2: Of course we studied grammar, wrote essays and so on the course, but I think I learn most just by listening, speaking and constantly being "surrounded by English", written and spoken.

column1: Now , when going to study English again ( and this time on a more advanced degree ) , I feel a bit unused to it because I have n't practised it for a while .
column2: Now, when going to study English again (and this time on a more advanced level), I feel a bit unused to it because I haven't practised it for a while.

column1: But I think , or at least hope , it will be quite comfortable to get into it again , at least the listening part .
column2: But I think, or at least hope, it will be quite easy to get into it again, at least the listening part.

column1: I remember that is the easiest thing , unless the speaker has got some , for me unknown , dialect or anything .
column2: I think that is the easiest thing, unless the speaker has got some, for me unknown, dialect or anything.

column1: When it comes to reading I think it depends very much of what you are reading , whether it is unmanageable or not .
column2: When it comes to reading I think it depends very much of what you are reading, whether it is difficult or not.

column1: When reading an English-written novel , I may not understand exactly all of the words , but I can get the floor on the whole anyway .
column2: When reading an English-written novel, I may not understand exactly all of the words, but I can get the story on the whole anyway.

column1: If reading specialist literature , though , it might be a bit more difficult , due to the fact that there may be lots of words that I normally make n't get into contact with .
column2: If reading specialist literature, though, it might be a bit more difficult, due to the fact that there may be lots of words that I normally don't get into contact with.

column1: According to speaking , as I mentioned before , I think it 's a question of self-reliance for me .
column2: According to speaking, as I mentioned before, I think it's a question of self-reliance for me.

column1: When I was in England I think I improved my speaking ability a lot , at least to use the language in casual speech .
column2: When I was in England I think I improved my speaking ability a lot, at least to use the language in everyday speech.

column1: I hope I will get into the language like that again now and also enlarge my vocabulary ( in writing as well , of course ) .
column2: I hope I will get into the language like that again now and also enlarge my vocabulary (in writing as well, of course).

column1: What I also would like to develop more is my pronunciation .
column2: What I also would like to develop more is my pronunciation.

column1: At this moment I think there is sometimes besides much a mix of Swedish- , American- , and British English in my language .
column2: At this moment I think there is sometimes too much a mix of Swedish-, American-, and British English in my language.

column1: My ambition is to get a consistently British pronunciation and fluency in my speaking .
column2: My dream is to get a consistently British pronunciation and fluency in my speaking.

column1: ( I think I have a retentive way to get there , though ! )
column2: (I think I have a long way to get there, though!)

column1: Concerning myself , I think , writing in English is the about difficult part .
column2: Concerning myself, I think, writing in English is the most difficult part.

column1: Maybe not spelling words right , but handling with the grammar right , knowing what expression or word burst where , and getting a clear structure in my composition , are , among other , things that I have to practise more .
column2: Maybe not spelling words right, but handling with the grammar right, knowing what expression or word fit where, and getting a clear structure in my composition, are, among other, things that I have to practise more.

column1: That 's common for all of the four skills that I 've noted - I have to practise a lot !
column2: That's common for all of the four skills that I've mentioned - I have to practise a lot!

column1: ﻿ LANGUAGE VARIETIES A study of vocabulary differences between British and American English 1 .
column2: ﻿ LANGUAGE VARIETIES A study of vocabulary differences between British and American English  1.

column1: Introduction The English language is spoken all over the world , it is the mother tongue of about 400 million people and about as many talk it as a second language .
column2: Introduction  The English language is spoken all over the world, it is the mother tongue of about 400 million people and about as many speak it as a second language.

column1: All speakers of English do not use the language in a uniform means though , there are many varieties of English .
column2: All speakers of English do not use the language in a uniform way though, there are many varieties of English.

column1: Of course there are more similarities than differences between the various varieties of English but the differences that make exist are still distinct enough to separate one variety from another .
column2: Of course there are more similarities than differences between the various varieties of English but the differences that do exist are still distinct enough to separate one variety from another.

column1: British English and American English are the two independent standard varieties of English and differences between these two main varieties can be found within all areas of language use ; in grammar , spelling , pronunciation , punctuation , vocabulary and style ( Ilson 1985 : 7 ) .
column2: British English and American English are the two main standard varieties of English and differences between these two main varieties can be found within all areas of language use; in grammar, spelling, pronunciation, punctuation, vocabulary and style (Ilson 1985: 7).

column1: The vocabulary differences are among the about numerous and they also seem to cause the most confusion .
column2: The vocabulary differences are among the most numerous and they also seem to cause the most confusion.

column1: The purpose of this essay is to disperse some of that confusion and rather , hopefully , shed some light on vocabulary differences between British English and American English .
column2: The purpose of this essay is to disperse some of that confusion and instead, hopefully, shed some light on vocabulary differences between British English and American English.

column1: I have chosen to limit the investigation to the culinary area , i.e .
column2: I have chosen to limit the investigation to the culinary area, i.e.

column1: words related to beverages , food and foodpreparing .
column2: words related to beverages, food and foodpreparing.

column1: What I intend to find out is ; how common the differences are , what types of differences there are and if one type is more frequent than the others .
column2: What I intend to find out is; how common the differences are, what types of differences there are and if one type is more frequent than the others.

column1: My primary material consists solely of the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English , from which I collected the inaugural 200 words I found that are related to food .
column2: My primary material consists solely of the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English, from which I collected the first 200 words I found that are related to food.

column1: I chose to collect words beginning with the letters c and s because those two letters are given the about space in the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English .
column2: I chose to collect words beginning with the letters c and s because those two letters are given the most space in the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English.

column1: I collected 100 words from each letter and singled out those which showed a difference between British English and American English .
column2: I collected 100 words from each letter and singled out those which showed a difference between British English and American English.

column1: Then I categorised them according to the classification used by Trudgill and Hannah ( 1985 ) , which consists of four major categories : 1 .
column2: Then I categorised them according to the classification used by Trudgill and Hannah (1985), which consists of four major categories: 1.

column1: Different word for the like concept or item , 2 .
column2: Different word for the same concept or item, 2.

column1: Same word-different meaning , 3 .
column2: Same word-different meaning, 3.

column1: Same word-additional meaning in one variety , 4 .
column2: Same word-additional meaning in one variety, 4.

column1: Word less frequent but understood in the early variety .
column2: Word less frequent but understood in the other variety.

column1: As I had expected the categorisation involved a few problems .
column2: As I had expected the categorisation involved a few problems.

column1: Firstly , some of the words seemed to belong to more than one category .
column2: Firstly, some of the words seemed to belong to more than one category.

column1: Secondly , since I am a non-native speaker of English and the relationship between British English and American English is quite complex it was very difficult to know which words to place where regarding the sub-types of the 1st category , and which words to put in category 4 .
column2: Secondly, since I am a non-native speaker of English and the relationship between British English and American English is quite complex it was very difficult to know which words to put where regarding the sub-types of the 1st category, and which words to put in category 4.

column1: To help solve the problems I used two British-American dictionaries ; Britspeak and Richard Smith 's Compendium of Britishisms .
column2: To help solve the problems I used two British-American dictionaries; Britspeak and Richard Smith's Compendium of Britishisms.

column1: After having made the classification I analysed the results and tried to put together a clear and easy to understand presentation which will follow in the next chapter .
column2: After having done the classification I analysed the results and tried to put together a clear and easy to understand presentation which will follow in the next chapter.

column1: All definitions of the words are according to the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English .
column2: All definitions of the words are according to the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English.

column1: Abbreviations that will be used in the presentation of the results are ; BrE for British English , AmE for American English .
column2: Abbreviations that will be used in the presentation of the results are; BrE for British English, AmE for American English.

column1: 2 Results Out of 200 words related to food 62 words , ( 33 beginning with c and 29 beginning with s ) , showed a difference between BrE and AmE .
column2: 2 Results  Out of 200 words related to food 62 words, (33 beginning with c and 29 beginning with s), showed a difference between BrE and AmE.

column1: The table below shows the distribution of the words into the unlike categories , 8 words appear in more than one category : Total number of words 62 Different word for the same item 44 Same word different meaning 10 Same word additional meaning in one variety 13 Word less frequent in one variety 7 2.1 Different word for the same concept or item According to Trudgill and Hannah ( 1985 ) the majority of lexical differences between BrE and AmE are of this type .
column2: The table below shows the distribution of the words into the different categories, 8 words appear in more than one category:     Total number of words        62   Different word for the same item    44 Same word different meaning    10 Same word additional meaning in one variety   13 Word less frequent in one variety  7  2.1 Different word for the same concept or item  According to Trudgill and Hannah (1985) the majority of lexical differences between BrE and AmE are of this type.

column1: That turned out to be the case also in my investigation , 44 out of 62 words belong to this category , though the 7 words marked with * appear in more than one category .
column2: That turned out to be the case also in my investigation, 44 out of 62 words belong to this category, though the 7 words marked with * appear in more than one category.

column1: The words in this category can be divided into two sub-types ; one where the word is not widely known in the early variety , and another where the word is known .
column2: The words in this category can be divided into two sub-types; one where the word is not widely known in the other variety, and another where the word is known.

column1: In the list below the words in bluff type are words that are widely known in the other variety : < table removed > 2.2 Same word - different meaning The words in this category are without a doubt the most confusing ones for speakers of BrE and AmE .
column2: In the list below the words in bold type are words that are widely known in the other variety:  <table removed>    2.2 Same word - different meaning  The words in this category are without a doubt the most confusing ones for speakers of BrE and AmE.

column1: Luckily these kinds of words are quite few in number as opposed to the previous category ( Trudgill and Hannah 1985 : 77 ) .
column2: Luckily these kinds of words are quite few in number as opposed to the previous category (Trudgill and Hannah 1985: 77).

column1: In my investigation 10 words out of 62 belong to this category : < table removed > 2.3 Same word - additional meaning in one variety The words belonging to this category are words that are frequently used in both BrE and AmE , but in one variety they have an additional meaning not known in the early .
column2: In my investigation 10 words out of 62 belong to this category:  <table removed>     2.3 Same word - additional meaning in one variety  The words belonging to this category are words that are frequently used in both BrE and AmE, but in one variety they have an additional meaning not known in the other.

column2: To sum up the result of this mini-investigation I think it is safe to say that it confirmed that vocabulary differences between British and American English are very common.

column2: Out of the 200 words that I collected 62 words showed a difference between the two varieties, that is 31% or almost 1/3 of the words.

column1: ﻿ Swedish education in danger In Sweden the Teachers ' Educational Committee ( LUK ) has proposed a reform of the Swedish teacher 's education programs and the Swedish parliament is soon to decide the future of Swedish school .
column2: ﻿ Swedish education in danger  In Sweden the Teachers' Educational Committee (LUK) has proposed a reform of the Swedish teacher's education programs and the Swedish parliament is soon to decide the future of Swedish school.

column1: The reform contains quiet drastic changes and has been intensively debated in Swedish media .
column2: The reform contains quiet drastic changes and has been intensively debated in Swedish media.

column1: One of the bigger changes is that less time will be spent on subject reports , an reduction from 120 academic points to only 40 possibly 60 academic points .
column2: One of the bigger changes is that less time will be spent on subject studies, an reduction from 120 academic points to only 40 possibly 60 academic points.

column1: In Dagens Nyheter Arne Hellden , lecturer at Linkeping University , gives the reader the main features of the reform and strongly argues against it .
column2: In Dagens Nyheter Arne Hellden, lecturer at Linkeping University, gives the reader the main features of the reform and strongly argues against it.

column1: Unfortunately the picture of what LUK 's reform consist of does not become very clear when Hellden is trying to explain the reform 's main features .
column2: Unfortunately the picture of what LUK's reform consist of does not get very clear when Hellden is trying to explain the reform's main features.

column1: However I will as well as Hellden , and in support of his article , argue against LUK 's proposal by explaining the absurdity of the reform and by arguing for the importance of having the present amount of subject reports .
column2: However I will as well as Hellden, and in support of his article, argue against LUK's proposal by explaining the absurdity of the reform and by arguing for the importance of having the present amount of subject studies.

column1: LUK 's reform looks just like a desperate attempt to reduce the increasing number of failing students .
column2: LUK's reform seems just like a desperate attempt to reduce the increasing number of failing students.

column1: Many alternations have been made in Swedish education during the concluding few years .
column2: Many alternations have been made in Swedish education during the last few years.

column1: The change that credibly has been most controversial and most troublesome is the alternation of the Swedish grade system at the senior level of the nine-year compulsory school and at upper secondary school .
column2: The change that probably has been most controversial and most troublesome is the alternation of the Swedish grade system at the senior level of the nine-year compulsory school and at upper secondary school.

column1: Earlier students could receive grades from one through five , where five was the highest and one the lowest .
column2: Earlier pupils could receive grades from one through five, where five was the highest and one the lowest.

column1: In 1994 the grade scale was transferred to grades failed , passed , passed with distinction , and passed with much distinction .
column2: In 1994 the grade scale was changed to grades failed, passed, passed with distinction, and passed with much distinction.

column1: Before the change the requirements for qualifying for upper secondary school was based entirely on the average grade , but then when the grading system changed it was also required to pass the subjects ; Swedish , Mathematics , and English .
column2: Before the change the requirements for qualifying for upper secondary school was based only on the average grade, but then when the grading system changed it was also required to pass the subjects; Swedish, Mathematics, and English.

column1: The consequence was that many students failed one of the required subjects and could not move on to upper secondary .
column2: The consequence was that many pupils failed one of the required subjects and could not move on to upper secondary.

column1: The situation has unfortunately grown bad and politicians are desperately looking for solutions .
column2: The situation has unfortunately grown worse and politicians are desperately looking for solutions.

column1: If believing great changes in education will solve the problem of failing students , this reform of teachers ' education proposed by LUK could definitely be a solution to the problem .
column2: If believing great changes in education will solve the problem of failing pupils, this reform of teachers' education proposed by LUK could definitely be a solution to the problem.

column1: However , I do not believe that reducing subject studies will solve any trouble , only create more .
column2: However, I do not believe that reducing subject studies will solve any problem, only create more.

column1: Those responsible for the reform do obviously not gain the importance of subject knowledge .
column2: Those responsible for the reform do obviously not realise the importance of subject knowledge.

column1: According to Hellden the expert pedagogues that have determined LUK are more interested in educating student teachers how knowledge is formed and organised rather than letting them acquire knowledge .
column2: According to Hellden the expert pedagogues that have influenced LUK are more interested in educating student teachers how knowledge is formed and organised rather than letting them acquire knowledge.

column1: This is presumably an attempt to add more pedagogic to teachers ' education programs , which certainly is of great importance .
column2: This is presumably an attempt to add more pedagogic to teachers' education programs, which certainly is of great importance.

column1: However , I believe that the present teachers ' education programs include enough of pedagogic .
column2: However, I believe that the present teachers' education programs include enough of pedagogic.

column1: There is definitely no need for such a pedagogic form earlier mentioned , which looks more like mumbo jumbo than a serious suggestion .
column2: There is definitely no need for such a pedagogic form earlier mentioned, which seems more like mumbo jumbo than a serious suggestion.

column1: In school children learn basic knowledge for future studies at college and University .
column2: In school children learn basic knowledge for future studies at college and University.

column1: This basic knowledge is based on simple facts and uncomplicated structure , and does not require knowledge of how knowledge is formed and organised when teaching it .
column2: This basic knowledge is based on simple facts and uncomplicated structure, and does not require knowledge of how knowledge is formed and organised when teaching it.

column1: What is considerable , however , is that teachers acknowledge their subjects .
column2: What is considerable, however, is that teachers know their subjects.

column1: If reducing subject reports to less than half of what the present teacher 's education programs have , teachers might lose their authority as being an academically learned teacher .
column2: If reducing subject studies to less than half of what the present teacher's education programs have, teachers might lose their authority as being an academically learned teacher.

column1: Pupils or their parents may question teachers ' ability to teach if they do not have enough subject knowledge .
column2: Pupils or their parents may question teachers' ability to teach if they do not have enough subject knowledge.

column1: Having authority is an essential part of being a teacher .
column2: Having authority is an essential part of being a teacher.

column1: Teachers must feel their students respect them and that they can share their knowledge and play an important role in their pupils ' learning .
column2: Teachers must feel their pupils respect them and that they can share their knowledge and play an important role in their pupils' learning.

column1: Teachers of today has a base of subject knowledge , they know their subjects and find secure about teaching .
column2: Teachers of today has a base of subject knowledge, they know their subjects and feel secure about teaching.

column1: However , the future teacher function seems very worrying if LUK 's reform is approved in the Swedish parliament .
column2: However, the future teacher role seems very worrying if LUK's reform is approved in the Swedish parliament.

column1: Teacher will not longer be teaching their students , but guiding them through the world of knowledge as experts in how knowledge is formed and organised .
column2: Teacher will not longer be teaching their pupils, but guiding them through the world of knowledge as experts in how knowledge is formed and organised.

column1: Some politicians might think LUK 's reform of teachers ' education programs will solve the problem of failing pupils and other problems they earlier caused .
column2: Some politicians might believe LUK's reform of teachers' education programs will solve the problem of failing pupils and other problems they earlier caused.

column1: However , hopefully most politicians will gain the absurdity of this suggestion .
column2: However, hopefully most politicians will realise the absurdity of this suggestion.

column1: ﻿ People 's fear of the unknown As I see it , the independent theme of The Fifth Child is that we people are afraid of matters that we are not familiar with , things we do not understand , it is about people 's fear of the unknown and their different ways of dealing with it .
column2: ﻿ People's fear of the unknown  As I see it, the main theme of The Fifth Child is that we people are afraid of matters that we are not familiar with, things we do not understand, it is about people's fear of the unknown and their different ways of dealing with it.

column2: What we are not familiar with, we do not like and sometimes the unknown scares us.

column2: Naturally Harriet and the rest think there is something wrong with Ben, and they are afraid of him because they do not understand him.

column2: Ben represents the abnormal in the book and by his parents and relatives fear of him we are shown how people might react when they confront something they are not familiar with.

column2: But Ben cannot be changed or manipulated, he is who he is.
