column1: ﻿At the age of 20 , I nowadays look back at my English studies and it seems unreal that ten years have gone by since I was in the 4th grade , which was my first year of English .
column2: ﻿At the age of 20, I now look back at my English studies and it seems unreal that ten years have gone by since I was in the 4th grade, which was my first year of English.

column1: I can however remember how we sang `` John Brown '' and practiced the colors by writing a book .
column2: I can still remember how we sang "John Brown" and practiced the colors by writing a book.

column1: Everybody also had to choose a name from an English speaking area .
column2: Everybody also had to choose a name from an English speaking country.

column1: Most of my classmates had a name from the American soap opera `` Dallas '' , such as Pamela , Bobby , and Jenna .
column2: Most of my classmates had a name from the American soap opera "Dallas", such as Pamela, Bobby, and Jenna.

column1: I was called Patricia , a name , which my mom came up with .
column2: I was called Patricia, a name, which my mom came up with.

column1: These are my inaugural memories from studying English .
column2: These are my first memories from studying English.

column1: In elementary school , English was more a game than a national and I loved it .
column2: In elementary school, English was more a game than a subject and I loved it.

column1: In middle school I started with German and I felt that my English was neglected , which actually worried me .
column2: In middle school I started with German and I felt that my English was neglected, which really worried me.

column1: German was hard but very logical and I knew and understood the grammar .
column2: German was hard but very logical and I knew and understood the grammar.

column1: I could tell the German prepositions in my sleep , whereas I did not know anything about the English prepositions .
column2: I could tell the German prepositions in my sleep, whereas I did not know anything about the English prepositions.

column1: After middle school I began to dream of a school year abroad .
column2: After middle school I began to dream of a school year abroad.

column1: I made up my mind as I started eminent school , not only because I was worried about my English skills , but also because I longed for adventure .
column2: I made up my mind as I started high school, not only because I was worried about my English skills, but also because I longed for adventure.

column1: Thanks to my parents this dream became truthful in 1996 .
column2: Thanks to my parents this dream became true in 1996.

column1: After my second year of high school I left for Indiana , U.S.A. My motion for this paper is : what have I learned during these ten years of studying English ?
column2: After my second year of high school I left for Indiana, U.S.A.  My question for this paper is: what have I learned during these ten years of studying English?

column1: Which are my strengths and weaknesses in the four skills of listening , reading , speaking , and writing ?
column2: Which are my strengths and weaknesses in the four skills of listening, reading, speaking, and writing?

column1: As a result of my school year in the U.S. my ears have become very familiar with the sound of the English language at an everyday level , specially American English .
column2: As a result of my school year in the U.S. my ears have become very familiar with the sound of the English language at an everyday level, especially American English.

column1: My time abroad forced me to actually listen and pay attention to what people said .
column2: My time abroad forced me to really listen and pay attention to what people said.

column1: Since everything was in English I learned precisely by living there .
column2: Since everything was in English I learned just by living there.

column1: I do not have a problem understanding spoken English at an everyday level , but I am very mindful of the differences in levels and I know that I still have a long way to go .
column2: I do not have a problem understanding spoken English at an everyday level, but I am very aware of the differences in levels and I know that I still have a long way to go.

column1: When it comes to reading the school in Sweden spent quite some time on that , at least at the eminent school level .
column2: When it comes to reading the school in Sweden spent quite some time on that, at least at the high school level.

column1: Studying in the U.S.A .
column2: Studying in the U.S.A.

column1: I also had to do a lot of reading , which I sometimes found unmanageable , especially in classes such as government and economics , since there were so many terms that I was not familiar with .
column2: I also had to do a lot of reading, which I sometimes found difficult, especially in classes such as government and economics, since there were so many terms that I was not familiar with.

column1: I do fine reading novels and I have learned to use the context when there are words that I do not know .
column2: I do fine reading novels and I have learned to use the context when there are words that I do not know.

column1: I enjoy reading novels in English , but I find it harder to understand shorter texts .
column2: I enjoy reading novels in English, but I find it harder to understand shorter texts.

column1: possibly I need more information to really get it .
column2: Perhaps I need more information to really get it.

column1: A time limit stresses me and I tend to read too fast ; that is probably why I have a trouble with short stories , and I never did as good as I wanted to on reading and comprehension tests in high school .
column2: A time limit stresses me and I tend to read too fast; that is probably why I have a problem with short stories, and I never did as good as I wanted to on reading and comprehension tests in high school.

column1: Due to my time in the U.S.A. with the Americans my spoken English grew tremendously .
column2: Due to my time in the U.S.A. with the Americans my spoken English developed tremendously.

column1: I did not understand how much my school English had changed until my sisters came to see me ; I had then been in the U.S.A. for one semester .
column2: I did not realize how much my school English had changed until my sisters came to see me; I had then been in the U.S.A. for one semester.

column1: Listening to their English I understood that my English had been given an American touch .
column2: Listening to their English I understood that my English had been given an American touch.

column1: I learned to use fresh words and speak although I was not sure that it was correct .
column2: I learned to use new words and speak although I was not sure that it was correct.

column1: I came to the point where I let myself to make mistakes and I let people laugh at me .
column2: I came to the point where I allowed myself to make mistakes and I let people laugh at me.

column1: Sometimes my tongue actually got twisted and I said the craziest things , yet my mistakes taught me more than I would ever have learned if I had been quiet .
column2: Sometimes my tongue really got twisted and I said the craziest things, yet my mistakes taught me more than I would ever have learned if I had been quiet.

column1: Speaking English sometimes makes me anxious , and in a strange way I feel more relaxed speaking English with , or in front of , English native speakers than I do with my countrymen .
column2: Speaking English sometimes makes me nervous, and in a strange way I feel more relaxed speaking English with, or in front of, English native speakers than I do with my countrymen.

column1: Writing is the skill in which I have not had very much practice , not even in the U.S.A. since the tests were constantly made up of matching or multiple choice questions .
column2: Writing is the skill in which I have not had very much practice, not even in the U.S.A. since the tests were always made up of matching or multiple choice questions.

column1: My third , and last , class of high school in Sweden I took a class called `` English C '' and there we actually practiced writing .
column2: My third, and last, year of high school in Sweden I took a class called "English C" and there we actually practiced writing.

column1: We wrote formal letters , personal notes , leaflets , and book reviews .
column2: We wrote formal letters, personal notes, leaflets, and book reviews.

column1: I get a lot of practice by my own since I have thus many friends in the U.S.A. to whom I frequently write letters and e-mail messages .
column2: I get a lot of practice by my own since I have so many friends in the U.S.A. to whom I frequently write letters and e-mail messages.

column1: A big problem that I have when I write is that I neither feel comfortable with my spelling , nor my grammar .
column2: A big problem that I have when I write is that I neither feel comfortable with my spelling, nor my grammar.

column1: In early words : I really need more writing exercises .
column2: In other words: I really need more writing exercises.

column1: Finally , I want to point out that I have learned a lot during these ten years but still ten years is a long time and I find that I could have learned more than I did .

column1: Nineteenth century attitudes to female education During the later part of the 19th century British feminists and other groups in company began to question whether British women were entitled to education in the same extent as men or not .
column2: Nineteenth century attitudes to female education  During the later part of the 19th century British feminists and other groups in society began to question whether British women were entitled to education in the same extent as men or not.

column1: A young woman 's teens was nevertheless only a preparation for motherhood , at least that was the chief opinion during this period in time .
column2: A young woman's teens was nevertheless only a preparation for motherhood, at least that was the main opinion during this period in time.

column1: Schooling was considered a way for a young girl to become social rather than intellectual skills , and that was something that she could get at home .
column2: Schooling was considered a way for a young girl to get social rather than intellectual skills, and that was something that she could get at home.

column1: What these reformists made n't consider was the fact that in order to make female education possible they would have to change the common way people thought of women , as mothers .
column2: What these reformists didn't consider was the fact that in order to make female education possible they would have to change the common way people thought of women, as mothers.

column1: And let 's be honest , there were more arguments against than for educating the British woman .
column2: And let's be honest, there were more arguments against than for educating the British woman.

column1: Opponents used everything from medical conditions , such as brain capacity , to economic disadvantages to make their degree .
column2: Opponents used everything from medical conditions, such as brain capacity, to economic disadvantages to make their point.

column1: What came to be a turning point in female education was the question regarding the British woman 's character as a mother for future Englishmen .
column2: What came to be a turning point in female education was the question regarding the British woman's role as a mother for future Englishmen.

column1: In order for Britain to remain a character model for other countries the British woman had to be educated in skills other than needlework and music to be a satisfactory mother for the future sons of Britain , at least that was the arguments used by the reformists .
column2: In order for Britain to remain a role model for other countries the British woman had to be educated in skills other than needlework and music to be a satisfactory mother for the future sons of Britain, at least that was the arguments used by the reformists.

column1: Opponents nevertheless continued to claim that women could n't study the like subjects as men and certainly not in the same pace because men simply were more intelligent than women were .
column2: Opponents nevertheless continued to claim that women couldn't study the same subjects as men and certainly not in the same pace because men simply were more intelligent than women were.

column1: disputes between women and men regarding intellectual skills were constantly debated when trying to reform women 's right for education .
column2: Differences between women and men regarding intellectual skills were constantly debated when trying to reform women's right for education.

column1: What seemed to be a typical woman attribute was that she was insightful and sensitive , hence quick to catch a point .
column2: What seemed to be a typical woman attribute was that she was insightful and sensitive, hence quick to catch a point.

column1: On the early hand she had no ability to concentrate or weigh evidence in making a judgement , hence she had no stamina for studying in higher institutions .
column2: On the other hand she had no ability to concentrate or weigh evidence in making a judgement, hence she had no stamina for studying in higher institutions.

column1: Opponents to female education claimed that the world had not produced any women counterparts to bang-up men like Mozart , Shakespeare or Raphael .
column2: Opponents to female education claimed that the world had not produced any women counterparts to great men like Mozart, Shakespeare or Raphael.

column1: There were two early arguments that the opponents used against female education .
column2: There were two other arguments that the opponents used against female education.

column1: First , as education was very costly , entirely those with the highest potential should receive education .
column2: First, as education was very costly, only those with the highest potential should receive education.

column1: Men had higher status and thought to get higher potential than women and should therefor be prioritized to receive education .
column2: Men had higher status and thought to have higher potential than women and should therefor be prioritized to receive education.

column1: The second argument used were that the higher up one went the educational ladder the less value was there in educating women since they were not capable of great creative work and had less concentration skills .
column2: The second argument used was that the higher up one went the educational ladder the less value was there in educating women since they were not capable of great creative work and had less concentration skills.

column1: What opponents used , as an argument for this , was the medical condition that men had bigger brains than women did and therefor women were unable to perceive , let alone share , the great creative powers of men .
column2: What opponents used, as an argument for this, was the medical condition that men had bigger brains than women did and therefor women were unable to comprehend, let alone share, the great creative powers of men.

column1: There was therefor no point in trying to make girls study the like subjects as boys ; it was a waste of time and money .
column2: There was therefor no point in trying to make girls study the same subjects as boys; it was a waste of time and money.

column1: Those few women who possessed the necessary skills for higher education were supposed to be a poor example of womanhood .
column2: Those few women who possessed the necessary skills for higher education were said to be a poor example of womanhood.

column1: As Miss Becker puts it , `` They could hardly be considered well-developed specimens of womanhood '' .
column2: As Miss Becker puts it, "They could hardly be considered well-developed specimens of womanhood".

column1: Education for girls were , as mentioned before , seen merely was a preparation for marriage for new girls .
column2: Education for girls were, as mentioned before, seen merely was a preparation for marriage for young girls.

column1: They were taught entirely accomplishments suitable for their roles as good wives and mothers .
column2: They were taught only accomplishments suitable for their roles as good wives and mothers.

column1: Feminists claimed that women needed skills similar to men 's if they were to remain unmarried .
column2: Feminists claimed that women needed skills similar to men's if they were to remain unmarried.

column1: This argument was unfortunately not one that made much effect on the debate .
column2: This argument was unfortunately not one that made much effect on the debate.

column1: What rather became the turning point in the discussion about female education was just the question about motherhood .
column2: What instead became the turning point in the discussion about female education was just the question about motherhood.

column1: What people ( mostly men ) began to understand that educating the women of Britain was important because `` they were to be the mothers of Englishmen '' ( Sally Mitchell ) and wanted domestic skills in order to perform satisfactory in this situation .
column2: What people (mostly men) began to understand that educating the women of Britain was important because "they were to be the mothers of Englishmen" (Sally Mitchell) and needed domestic skills in order to perform satisfactory in this situation.

column2: The reformists used the opponents' arguments about motherhood against them and tried to scare them into think that the British women were unable to perform satisfactory in their role, as mothers, if they hadn't received the proper education required for the situation.

column1: ﻿ Fantasy- an endangered species .
column2: ﻿ Fantasy- an endangered species.

column1: In today 's company , television is a great part of people 's lives , mostly used for entertainment but also for civic information .
column2: In today's society, television is a great part of people's lives, mostly used for entertainment but also for civic information.

column1: However , as people , and especially children , spend an increasing amount of time in front of the television instead of turning to books or storytelling , it is time to be concerned .
column2: However, as people, and especially children, spend an increasing amount of time in front of the television instead of turning to books or storytelling, it is time to be concerned.

column1: It is my belief that television endangers our imagination and that children of today , therefore , might turn up to have a somewhat poorer capability of fantasizing than we do now .
column2: It is my belief that television endangers our imagination and that children of today, therefore, might grow up to have a somewhat poorer capability of fantasizing than we do now.

column1: About a hundred years ago , I spent every Monday evening baby-sitting my youngest neighbour , a four- year-old boy who loved watching television .
column2: About a hundred years ago, I spent every Monday evening baby-sitting my youngest neighbour, a four- year-old boy who loved watching television.

column1: When I arrived , he usually sat in front of it already but since I found Ducktales extremely dull , I grabbed every opportunity trying to persuade him to play any sort of game .
column2: When I arrived, he usually sat in front of it already but since I found Ducktales extremely dull, I grabbed every opportunity trying to persuade him to play any sort of game.

column1: One evening I got him engaged in a game of make-believe and we were pretending to be Robin Hood and Little John on a mission to free the lovely Lady Marion ( need I mention that he was Robin ) .
column2: One evening I got him engaged in a game of make-believe and we were pretending to be Robin Hood and Little John on a mission to free the lovely Lady Marion (need I mention that he was Robin).

column1: As the skilful sword-fighters we were , the villains were overpowered with ease and we were able to break into the dungeon ( the bathroom ) where the fair maiden was imprisoned .
column2: As the skilful sword-fighters we were, the villains were overpowered with ease and we were able to break into the dungeon (the bathroom) where the fair maiden was imprisoned.

column1: We entered and I stretched out my hand : `` Come Marion , let us leave '' .
column2: We entered and I stretched out my hand: "Come Marion, let us leave".

column1: The boy instantly let go of his fantasy sword , starred at me and said : `` Karin , that 's a bathtub . ''
column2: The boy instantly let go of his fantasy sword, starred at me and said: "Karin, that's a bathtub."

column1: I was astounded and completely dumb-struck for a while , suddenly realising that the boy were not able to see the fantasy-world in his mind , the way I did .
column2: I was astounded and completely dumb-struck for a while, suddenly realising that the boy were not able to see the fantasy-world in his head, the way I did.

column1: I think of this episode with amusement but also great sadness .
column2: I think of this episode with amusement but also great sadness.

column1: I believe it to reflect a matter of considerable concern for our entire society , namely , the risk of losing the ability to fantasize as a result of replacing reading and story-telling with television .
column2: I believe it to reflect a matter of considerable concern for our entire society, namely, the risk of losing the ability to fantasize as a result of replacing reading and story-telling with television.

column1: When we take or get told a story , we are able to create an inner image around the events that take place .
column2: When we read or get told a story, we are able to create an inner image around the events that take place.

column1: Thus , we can partially decide for ourselves what the characters in the fairy-tales look like , what the setting is like and , using our imagination , we are able to paint a vivid picture of this in our own minds .
column2: Thus, we can partially decide for ourselves what the characters in the fairy-tales look like, what the setting is like and, using our imagination, we are able to paint a vivid picture of this in our own minds.

column1: This procedure contributes greatly to the ability of creating fantasies .
column2: This process contributes greatly to the ability of creating fantasies.

column1: When we watch television , on the other hand , we do not get the opportunity to work the information the same way , using our imagination .
column2: When we watch television, on the other hand, we do not get the opportunity to process the information the same way, using our imagination.

column1: All images are pre-made , not leaving much room for the valuable interpretation .
column2: All images are pre-made, not leaving much room for the valuable interpretation.

column1: In the end , this might lead to a decreasing need for imagination but also to damage on the gift of being able to fantisize .
column2: In the end, this might lead to a decreasing need for imagination but also to damage on the gift of being able to fantisize.

column1: Obviously , all television programs can not be considered harmful and maybe it is the amount of time spent on television , instead of creative activities , that constitutes the problem .
column2: Obviously, all television programs cannot be considered harmful and maybe it is the amount of time spent on television, instead of creative activities, that constitutes the problem.

column1: However , a lot of the content on today 's children 's shows is violent .
column2: However, much of the content on today's children's shows is violent.

column1: This might well be one reason why my neighbour was able to battle the villains , yet finding it difficult to visualize the `` dungeon '' and `` Marion '' .
column2: This might well be one reason why my neighbour was able to battle the villains, yet finding it difficult to visualize the "dungeon" and "Marion".

column1: I do not believe in vague explanations like little boys are born with an innate desire to fight .
column2: I do not believe in vague explanations like little boys are born with an innate desire to fight.

column1: I think they learn from society ( as do little girls , in fact ) , and if so , violence on television should be avoided .
column2: I believe they learn from society (as do little girls, in fact), and if so, violence on television should be avoided.

column1: Children are very impressionable and if they rely on television for giving them truths and facts about life , this might lead to less knowledge about human nature and an escalation of violence .
column2: Children are very impressionable and if they rely on television for giving them truths and facts about life, this might lead to less knowledge about human nature and an escalation of violence.

column1: To sum up , I think it would be fantastic if the children 's programs were filled with sensible messages with the intention of bringing up children to be intelligent and imaginative adults .
column2: To sum up, I believe it would be fantastic if the children's programs were filled with sensible messages with the intention of bringing up children to be intelligent and imaginative adults.

column1: Unfortunately , that is not case and the amount of time children spend watching television will credibly turn out to be unhealthy for forming fantasies .
column2: Unfortunately, that is not case and the amount of time children spend watching television will probably turn out to be unhealthy for forming fantasies.

column1: Hopefully , the danger with television is just a figment of my imagination , but if the signs keep coming , we need to wise up and prevent this from happening .
column2: Hopefully, the danger with television is just a figment of my imagination, but if the signs keep coming, we need to wise up and prevent this from happening.

column1: After all , fantasy is an amazing and powerful tool for keeping our existence vibrant and meaningful .
column2: After all, fantasy is an amazing and powerful tool for keeping our existence vibrant and meaningful.

column1: ﻿ The Industrialization in Britain : Its effects on Women and Children In the 18th and the 19th century , during the Age of nirvana , applied science led to many inventions which in turn led to the evolution of the Industrial Revolution .

column1: Examples are the steam power and the mass exploitation of coal ; energy sources necessary for the industrial mass production .
column2: Examples are the steam power and the mass exploitation of coal; energy sources necessary for the industrial mass production.

column2: Coal mining thus became an important industry in Britain.

column2: Another important invention was the spinning machine, the so-called spinning jenny, which led to the growth of the textile industry.

column2: Many people moved from the rural areas to the emerging cities in the 19th century.

column2: In the beginning of the 19th century women were not supposed to work outside their homes (Culture Kit, p.  121).

column2: They usually got married quite young and were economically dependent on their men.

column1: ﻿ `` The new order of things proposed '' : Vision and Reality in Robert Owen 's New Lanark and New Harmony .
column2: ﻿ "The new order of things proposed": Vision and Reality in Robert Owen's New Lanark and New Harmony.

column1: The Welsh manufacturer Robert Owen made respective community experiments in the early 19th century .
column2: The Welsh manufacturer Robert Owen made several community experiments in the early 19th century.

column1: Two of them were the experiments in New Lanark , Scotland , and New Harmony , Indiana , in the U.S. New Lanark was Owen 's first social experiment where he made a village with a cotton mill into a model community .
column2: Two of them were the experiments in New Lanark, Scotland, and New Harmony, Indiana, in the U.S.  New Lanark was Owen's first social experiment where he made a village with a cotton mill into a model community.

column1: New Harmony was a later attempt of Owen to make a self-contained community .
column2: New Harmony was a later attempt of Owen to create a self-contained community.

column1: In this essay I will present significant aspects of these two experiments in order to compare them .
column2: In this essay I will present important aspects of these two experiments in order to compare them.

column1: In the early 1800 's the Welshman Robert Owen , who was a partner in a Manchester firm , became a manager of the New Lanark mill in Lanarkshire in Scotland .
column2: In the early 1800's the Welshman Robert Owen, who was a partner in a Manchester firm, became a manager of the New Lanark mill in Lanarkshire in Scotland.

column1: Owen was confronted with bad living conditions as well as bad working conditions in the factory .
column2: Owen was confronted with bad living conditions as well as bad working conditions in the factory.

column1: Child labour was very common , theft was extensive , the workers had poor housing circumstances in squalid surroundings and there was no education for children .
column2: Child labour was very common, theft was extensive, the workers had poor housing conditions in squalid surroundings and there was no education for children.

column1: Owen immediately turned the fiddling village with the cotton mill as a nucleus into a `` welfare program '' .
column2: Owen immediately turned the little village with the cotton mill as a nucleus into a "welfare program".

column1: Owen improved many conditions such as the workers ' food , clothes , houses and the cleanliness in the factory .
column2: Owen improved many conditions such as the workers' food, clothes, houses and the cleanliness in the factory.

column1: He prevented drunkenness by starting to sell alcohol under strict control .
column2: He prevented drunkenness by starting to sell alcohol under strict control.

column1: Best known is that he started an education for children .
column2: Best known is that he started an education for children.

column1: Owen agreed that all these improvements in New Lanark would promote the productivity of the cotton mill and therefore the improvements fostered efficiency at the same time as they composed a type of social reform .
column2: Owen agreed that all these improvements in New Lanark would promote the productivity of the cotton mill and thus the improvements fostered efficiency at the same time as they composed a type of social reform.

column1: Naturally the improvements of the community fee-tailed expenses but Owen maintained that this would make the mill more profitable .
column2: Naturally the improvements of the community entailed expenses but Owen maintained that this would make the mill more profitable.

column1: Owen 's chief philosophy was that man 's character is formed in early childhood , not by himself , but for him , and only by the environment .
column2: Owen's main philosophy was that man's character is formed in early childhood, not by himself, but for him, and only by the environment.

column1: To create a good character man should be placed under good influences in the early days .
column2: To create a good character man should be placed under good influences in the early years.

column1: Owen further believed that company had a responsibility to offer good living conditions and education for the people .
column2: Owen further believed that society had a responsibility to offer good living conditions and education for the people.

column1: By improving many bad conditions in New Lanark he offered the workers a good life .
column2: By improving many bad conditions in New Lanark he offered the workers a better life.

column1: Owen agreed that he had changed the character of the New Lanark inhabitants by his alterations .
column2: Owen agreed that he had changed the character of the New Lanark inhabitants by his alterations.

column1: The fact is that Owen did n't intend to change the New Lanark mill 's basic character but he wanted to create new , good conditions in the mill .
column2: The fact is that Owen didn't intend to change the New Lanark mill's basic character but he wanted to create new, better conditions in the mill.

column1: The children who were brought up in New Lanark were generally healthy and respected .
column2: The children who were brought up in New Lanark were generally healthy and respected.

column1: The mill in New Lanark was very productive and became a success and a model community .
column2: The mill in New Lanark was very productive and became a success and a model community.

column1: New Lanark was consequently a mill that Owen turned into a community , which is in contrast to one of his belated social experiments , New Harmony , which was rather a planned Utopia to which Owen gathered a number of people in order to put his theories , both social and economic , into practice .
column2: New Lanark was consequently a mill that Owen turned into a community, which is in contrast to one of his later social experiments, New Harmony, which was rather a planned Utopia to which Owen gathered a number of people in order to put his theories, both social and economic, into practice.

column1: In this project Owen adopted a new economic plan that he emphasised , where the size of the community was important from the point of view of production .
column2: In this project Owen followed a new economic plan that he emphasised, where the size of the community was important from the point of view of production.

column1: In 1825 Owen bought a great piece of land in Indiana which he renamed New Harmony .
column2: In 1825 Owen bought a great piece of land in Indiana which he renamed New Harmony.

column1: His plan was to make a self-contained community , intending that the people would be self-supporting , producing their own products together with other co-operative villages .
column2: His plan was to create a self-contained community, intending that the people would be self-supporting, producing their own products together with other co-operative villages.

column1: Owen thought that there was a special number of people ( about 1200 persons ) who could live in the community in order to keep it self-contained .
column2: Owen believed that there was a special number of people (about 1200 persons) who could live in the community in order to keep it self-contained.

column1: Many activities in the community , such as eating and cooking , would be collective .
column2: Many activities in the community, such as eating and cooking, would be collective.

column1: Before the start Owen invited `` the industrious and well disposed of all nations '' to come to this community and be inhabitants .
column2: Before the start Owen invited "the industrious and well disposed of all nations" to come to this community and be inhabitants.

column1: Many of those who came did n't turn away to be as willing to learn as the New Lanark inhabitants .
column2: Many of those who came didn't turn out to be as willing to learn as the New Lanark inhabitants.

column1: The community soon ran into difficulties since people were at odds about the form of government and the function of religion .
column2: The community soon ran into difficulties since people were at odds about the form of government and the role of religion.

column1: New Harmony was consequently a failure and did n't concluding long .
column2: New Harmony was consequently a failure and didn't last long.

column1: Owen withdrew from the project in 1828 .
column2: Owen withdrew from the project in 1828.

column1: New Harmony was therefore intended to be a model community which could live on its own and offer work to unemployed and people without housing .
column2: New Harmony was thus intended to be a model community which could live on its own and offer work to unemployed and people without housing.

column1: In this subject Owen turned to more general problems of society .
column2: In this case Owen turned to more general problems of society.

column1: An aspect of this was to cure pauperism and unemployment .
column2: An aspect of this was to cure pauperism and unemployment.

column1: This was in comparison to New Lanark where more specific problems were in focus , such as improving factory conditions .
column2: This was in comparison to New Lanark where more specific problems were in focus, such as improving factory conditions.

column1: However , both of the experiments were plans for social reorganisation , the by and by one being based on a self-supporting community .
column2: However, both of the experiments were plans for social reorganisation, the later one being based on a self-supporting community.

column1: The social aspect was also apparent since Owen 's experiments were focused on the lower classes of society .
column2: The social aspect was also apparent since Owen's experiments were focused on the lower classes of society.

column1: In his later experiment he wanted to decrease the widespread unemployment by putting up small communities ; in New Lanark he improved the conditions for a number of lower-class people .
column2: In his later experiment he wanted to decrease the widespread unemployment by setting up small communities; in New Lanark he improved the conditions for a number of lower-class people.

column1: Even if it was obvious that Owen was concerned with the economic aspects of his communities he constantly had in mind that man should have good living conditions .
column2: Even if it was obvious that Owen was concerned with the economic aspects of his communities he always had in mind that man should have good living conditions.

column1: He believed that company had the responsibility to offer these conditions to the people .
column2: He believed that society had the responsibility to offer these conditions to the people.

column1: Since the factory is the dominant part in man 's life it must be as full as possible so he can live in it , Owen maintained .
column2: Since the factory is the dominant part in man's life it must be as good as possible so he can live in it, Owen maintained.

column1: However , his purpose of his experiments were upon the community and not on the individual .
column2: However, his purpose of his experiments was upon the community and not on the individual.

column1: Owen 's chief philosophy , that man is formed by the environment and that he should be placed under a good influence , was something that he based all his work on .
column2: Owen's main philosophy, that man is formed by the environment and that he should be placed under a good influence, was something that he based all his work on.

column1: This was also something that Owen indeed tried to carry into effect by his social experiments .
column2: This was also something that Owen indeed tried to carry into effect by his social experiments.

column1: Happiness was a keyword for Owen 's work : `` The object of all human exertions is to be felicitous .
column2: Happiness was a keyword for Owen's work: "The object of all human exertions is to be happy.

column1: Happiness can not be attained , enjoyed and secured , unless all men possess health , actual knowledge and wealth . ''
column2: Happiness cannot be attained, enjoyed and secured, unless all men possess health, real knowledge and wealth."

column1: 1 Owen experiments had a pragmatic means of working .
column2: 1 Owen experiments had a pragmatic way of working.

column1: He tried to form guidelines or propose reforms that would make a new social environment for lower class people .
column2: He tried to form guidelines or propose reforms that would create a new social environment for lower class people.

column1: The fact is that his first attempt was a success while New Harmony did n't work in practice .
column2: The fact is that his first attempt was a success while New Harmony didn't work in practice.

column1: It was in the township of Dunwich , in a large and partly inhabited farmhouse set against a hillside four miles from the village and a mile and a half from any other dwelling , that Wilbur Whateley was born at 5 A.M. on Sunday , the moment of February , 1913 .

column1: Formalities were run through by bewildered officials , abnormal details were duly kept from press and public , and men were sent to Dunwich and Aylesbury to look up property and notify any who might be heirs of the late Wilbur Whateley .

column1: They found the countryside in great agitation , both because of the growing rumblings beneath the domed hills , and because of the unwonted malodor and the surging , lapping sounds which came increasingly from the great empty shell formed by Whateley’s boarded-up farmhouse .

column1: An almost interminable manuscript in strange characters , published in a huge ledger and adjudged a sort of diary because of the spacing and the variations in ink and penmanship , presented a baffling puzzle to those who found it on the old bureau which served as its owner’s desk .
column2: An almost interminable manuscript in strange characters, written in a huge ledger and adjudged a sort of diary because of the spacing and the variations in ink and penmanship, presented a baffling puzzle to those who found it on the old bureau which served as its owner’s desk.

column2: “Up thar in the rud beyont the glen, Mis’ Corey—they’s suthin’ ben thar!

column1: It smells like thunder , an’ all the bushes an’ little trees is pushed back from the rud like they’d a haouse ben went along of it .
column2: It smells like thunder, an’ all the bushes an’ little trees is pushed back from the rud like they’d a haouse ben moved along of it.

column1: An’ that ain’t the wust , nuther .
column2: An’ that ain’t the wust, nuther.

column1: They’s prints in the rud , Mis’ Corey—great raound prints as big as barrel-heads , all sunk daown deep like a elephant had ben along , entirely they’s a sight more nor four feet could make !
column2: They’s prints in the rud, Mis’ Corey—great raound prints as big as barrel-heads, all sunk daown deep like a elephant had ben along, only they’s a sight more nor four feet could make!

column1: I looked at one or two afore I function , an’ I see every one was covered with lines spreadin’ aout from one place , like as if big palm-leaf fans—twict or three times as big as any they is—hed of ben paounded daown into the rud .

column1: An’ the smell was awful , like what it is araound Wizard Whateley’s ol’ haouse .

column2: Mrs. Corey, unable to extract more information, began telephoning the neighbours; thus starting on its rounds the overture of panic that heralded the major terrors.

column1: When she got Sally Sawyer , housekeeper at Seth Bishop’s , the nearest home to Whateley’s , it became her turn to listen instead of transmit ; for Sally’s boy Chauncey , who slept poorly , had been up on the hill toward Whateley’s , and had dashed back in terror after one look at the place , and at the pasturage where Mr. Bishop’s cows had been left out all night .
column2: When she got Sally Sawyer, housekeeper at Seth Bishop’s, the nearest place to Whateley’s, it became her turn to listen instead of transmit; for Sally’s boy Chauncey, who slept poorly, had been up on the hill toward Whateley’s, and had dashed back in terror after one look at the place, and at the pasturage where Mr. Bishop’s cows had been left out all night.

column1: “Yes , Mis’ Corey , ” came Sally’s tremulous part over the party wire , “Cha’ncey he just come back a-postin’ , and couldn’t haff talk fer bein’ scairt !
column2: “Yes, Mis’ Corey,” came Sally’s tremulous voice over the party wire, “Cha’ncey he just come back a-postin’, and couldn’t haff talk fer bein’ scairt!

column1: He says Ol’ Whateley’s haouse is all blowed up , with the timbers scattered raound like they’d ben dynamite inwardly ; only the bottom floor ain’t through , but is all covered with a kind o’ tar-like stuff that smells awful an’ drips daown offen the aidges onto the graoun’ whar the side timbers is blown away .
column2: He says Ol’ Whateley’s haouse is all blowed up, with the timbers scattered raound like they’d ben dynamite inside; only the bottom floor ain’t through, but is all covered with a kind o’ tar-like stuff that smells awful an’ drips daown offen the aidges onto the graoun’ whar the side timbers is blown away.

column1: An’ they’s awful kinder marks in the yard , tew—great raound marks bigger raound than a hogshead , an’ all sticky with stuff like is on the blowed-up haouse .
column2: An’ they’s awful kinder marks in the yard, tew—great raound marks bigger raound than a hogshead, an’ all sticky with stuff like is on the blowed-up haouse.

column1: Cha’ncey he says they leads off into the medders , whar a bang-up swath wider’n a barn is matted daown , an’ all the stun walls tumbled every whichway wherever it goes .
column2: Cha’ncey he says they leads off into the medders, whar a great swath wider’n a barn is matted daown, an’ all the stun walls tumbled every whichway wherever it goes.

column1: “An’ he says , says he , Mis’ Corey , as haow he sot to look fer Seth’s caows , frighted ez he was ; an’ faound ’em in the upper pasture nigh the Devil’s Hop Yard in an awful form .
column2: “An’ he says, says he, Mis’ Corey, as haow he sot to look fer Seth’s caows, frighted ez he was; an’ faound ’em in the upper pasture nigh the Devil’s Hop Yard in an awful shape.

column1: Haff on ’em’s clean run , an’ nigh haff o’ them that’s left is sucked most dry o’ blood , with sores on ’em like they’s ben on Whateley’s cattle ever senct Lavinny’s black brat was born .

column1: Cha’ncey didn’t look keerful ter see whar the big matted-daown swath led arter it leff the pasturage , but he says he thinks it p’inted towards the glen rud to the village .

column1: “I tell ye , Mis’ Corey , they’s suthin’ afield as hadn’t orter be abroad , an’ I for one think that black Wilbur Whateley , as come to the bad eend he desarved , is at the bottom of the breedin’ of it .
column2: “I tell ye, Mis’ Corey, they’s suthin’ abroad as hadn’t orter be abroad, an’ I for one think that black Wilbur Whateley, as come to the bad eend he desarved, is at the bottom of the breedin’ of it.

column1: He wa’n’t all human hisself , I allus says to everybody ; an’ I think he an’ Ol’ Whateley must a raised suthin’ in that there nailed-up haouse as ain’t even thus human as he was .
column2: He wa’n’t all human hisself, I allus says to everybody; an’ I think he an’ Ol’ Whateley must a raised suthin’ in that there nailed-up haouse as ain’t even so human as he was.

column1: They’s allus ben unseen things araound Dunwich—livin’ things—as ain’t human an’ ain’t full fer human folks .
column2: They’s allus ben unseen things araound Dunwich—livin’ things—as ain’t human an’ ain’t good fer human folks.

column1: “The graoun’ was a-talkin’ lass night , an’ towards mornin’ Cha’ncey he heerd the whippoorwills thus laoud in Col’ Spring Glen he couldn’t sleep nun .

column2: Then he thought he heerd another faint-like saound over towards Wizard Whateley’s—a kinder rippin’ or tearin’ o’ wood, like some big box er crate was bein’ opened fur off.

column1: What with this an’ that , he didn’t git to sleep at all till sunup , an’ no sooner was he up this mornin’ , but he’s got to go over to Whateley’s an’ see what’s the matter .

column1: He see enough , I assure ye , Mis’ Corey !

column2: This dun’t mean no good, an’ I think as all the men-folks ought to git up a party an’ do suthin’.

column1: I know suthin’ awful’s abaout , an’ feel my time is nigh , though entirely Gawd knows jest what it is .

column1: “Did your Luther take accaount o’ whar them big tracks led tew ?

column1: From below no sound came , but entirely a distant , undefinable foetor ; and it is not to be wondered at that the men preferred to stay on the edge and argue , rather than descend and beard the unknown Cyclopean horror in its lair .

column1: Whatever the horror was , it could scale a sheer stony cliff of almost complete verticality ; and as the detectives climbed around to the hill’s summit by safer routes they saw that the trail ended—or rather , reversed—there .

column1: When a traveller in north central Massachusetts takes the improper fork at the junction of the Aylesbury pike just beyond Dean’s Corners he comes upon a lonely and curious country .

column1: The ground gets higher , and the brier-bordered stone walls press closer and closer against the ruts of the dusty , curving road .

column2: The summits are too rounded and symmetrical to give a sense of comfort and naturalness, and sometimes the sky silhouettes with especial clearness the queer circles of tall stone pillars with which most of them are crowned.

column2: Gorges and ravines of problematical depth intersect the way, and the crude wooden bridges always seem of dubious safety.

column2: As the hills draw nearer, one heeds their wooded sides more than their stone-crowned tops.

column1: Those sides loom up thus darkly and precipitously that one wishes they would keep their distance , but there is no road by which to escape them .
column2: Those sides loom up so darkly and precipitously that one wishes they would keep their distance, but there is no road by which to escape them.

column1: Once across , it is difficult to prevent the impression of a faint , malign odour about the village street , as of the massed mould and decay of centuries .

column1: It is always a relief to become clear of the place , and to follow the narrow road around the base of the hills and across the level country beyond till it rejoins the Aylesbury pike .

column1: Afterward one sometimes learns that one has been through Dunwich .
column2: Afterward one sometimes learns that one has been through Dunwich.

column1: Outsiders visit Dunwich as seldom as possible , and since a certain season of horror all the signboards pointing toward it have been led down .
column2: Outsiders visit Dunwich as seldom as possible, and since a certain season of horror all the signboards pointing toward it have been taken down.

column1: The scenery , judged by any average aesthetic canon , is more than commonly beautiful ; yet there is no influx of artists or summer tourists .
column2: The scenery, judged by any ordinary aesthetic canon, is more than commonly beautiful; yet there is no influx of artists or summer tourists.

column1: Two centuries ago , when talk of witch-blood , Satan-worship , and strange forest bearings was not laughed at , it was the custom to give reasons for avoiding the locality .
column2: Two centuries ago, when talk of witch-blood, Satan-worship, and strange forest presences was not laughed at, it was the custom to give reasons for avoiding the locality.

column1: Perhaps one reason—though it can not apply to uninformed strangers—is that the natives are now repellently decadent , having become far along that path of retrogression so common in many New England backwaters .

column1: The average of their intelligence is woefully low , whilst their annals reek of overt viciousness and of half-hidden murders , incests , and deeds of about unnamable violence and perversity .

column1: The old gentry , representing the two or three armigerous families which came from Salem in 1692 , have continued somewhat above the general level of decay ; though many branches are sunk into the sordid populace so deeply that only their names remain as a key to the origin they disgrace .

column1: No one , even those who have the facts concerning the recent horror , can say just what is the matter with Dunwich ; though old legends speak of unhallowed rites and conclaves of the Indians , amidst which they called forbidden shapes of darkness out of the great rounded hills , and made wild orgiastic prayers that were answered by loud crackings and rumblings from the ground below .

column1: In 1747 the Reverend Abijah Hoadley , newly come to the Congregational Church at Dunwich Village , preached a memorable sermon on the close presence of Satan and his imps ; in which he said : “It must be allow’d , that these Blasphemies of an infernall Train of Daemons are Matters of too common Knowledge to be deny’d ; the cursed Voices of Azazel and Buzrael , of Beelzebub and Belial , being heard now from under land by above a Score of credible Witnesses now living .

column1: I my self did not more than a Fortnight ago catch a very plain Discourse of evill Powers in the Hill behind my House ; wherein there were a Rattling and Rolling , Groaning , Screeching , and Hissing , such as no matter of this Earth cou’d raise up , and which must needs have come from those Caves that only black Magick can discover , and only the Divell unlock.” Mr. Hoadley disappeared soon after delivering this sermon ; but the text , printed in Springfield , is still extant .

column1: The curious manuscript record or diary of Wilbur Whateley , delivered to Miskatonic University for translation , had caused much worry and bafflement among the experts in languages both ancient and advanced ; its very alphabet , notwithstanding a general resemblance to the heavily shaded Arabic used in Mesopotamia , being absolutely unknown to any available authority .

column1: The final conclusion of the linguists was that the text represented an artificial alphabet , giving the effect of a nothing ; though none of the usual methods of cryptographic solution seemed to furnish any clue , even when applied on the basis of every tongue the writer might conceivably have used .

column1: All through late August he fortified himself with the massed lore of cryptography ; drawing upon the fullest resources of his own library , and wading night after night amidst the secret of Trithemius’ Poligraphia , Giambattista Porta’s De Furtivis Literarum Notis , De Vigenère’s Traité des Chiffres , Falconer’s Cryptomenysis Patefacta , Davys’ and Thicknesse’s eighteenth-century treatises , and such fairly modern authorities as Blair , von Marten , and Klüber’s Kryptographik .

column1: He interspersed his study of the records with attacks on the manuscript itself , and in time became convinced that he had to deal with one of those subtlest and most ingenious of cryptograms , in which many separate lists of corresponding letters are arranged like the multiplication table , and the message built up with arbitrary key-words known only to the initiated .

column1: Weakly rising , he gathered up the scribbled papers and sealed them all in a great envelope , which he immediately put in his inside coat pocket .
